This is a great article, but for one thing. The concept of a national economy and therefore a national debt is almost completely outdated.

If one looks at interdependent trade, and interdependent debt, one finds that most economies are now dependently linked. That's the primary flaw with current economic mental models. There are no truly stand alone economies.

I've worked most of my life with factories in 40 nations shipping to and receiving from factories in other nations. Lately I'm watching funds flows on global electronic networks.

Look at Google's financial statements. They spend more than ten billion dollars buying web traffic from smaller sites around the world. That's money shared worldwide in real time, not US cash

After the 2007 crash I traveled to small towns in northern Norway because I wanted to see first hand how a village in basically a socialist country with oil money could lose 20% of its pension funds owing to bad housing lending policies in the US. I saw how Las Vegas foreclosures affected villages in Norway

The US is currently not behaving more like Greece because we are borrowing from everyone else

When one looks at the real flow of funds, not the statistically smoothed GDP it is clear we are all riding the debt wave together I am by no means predicting disaster, but it is time our theoreticians caught up with the real flows of funds worldwide. Get out of the office. Follow the money for real

A late friend, a doctor who worked at Rikers Island, told me that she had hepatitis-C and was in need of a liver transplant. Remembering how courageous she was in the face of it all, how excited we were when she was told that she could have one; the times she visited with a large box of pills placed on the kitchen counter, which kept her alive and with minor discomfort.

She never spoke much about it, and lived for a few more years, quite happy, always making plans. and leaving me in a state of awe at her will and spirit to live. Up at dawn, out for a walk in the City, having her breakfast, while I laid sprawled out on the living-room couch, looking like a Victorian invalid.

As for pills, she once told me 'there is no such thing as a happy one', bringing to mind the saying 'Candy is dandy; but liquor is faster'. Pills, she added, help sometimes to stabilize one's mood, and I believe she was right about this as well.

Unfortunately, this op-ed piece leads one to totally dismiss any and all natural cures and remedies discovered by Native Americans, Ancient Chinese, and many other cultures before Big Pharma ever existed to bully people into buying and using nothing but their laboratory produced hazardous products. Drug companies will suppress and convince physicians not to consider any natural products. The billions of dollars in profits every year at stake ensure that average Americans will never have the knowledge of and benefits of many, many remedies that existed before the drug giants took control of our medical profession.
This is not to say that modern drug discoveries are of no value and haven't saved millions of lives.

As female professor in the sciences, I see this all the time. I'm an excellent, enthusiastic, organized, humorous teacher who is fair and clear and great at getting students engaged. My evaluations are usually very good....sometimes I get the occasional vindictive student who didn't do the work and needs to blame someone. But, on the whole, I come out pretty well.

But I have quit reading my evaluations. More than my male colleagues, I can be judged in a nasty way by a few students and it hurts. After 30 years of teaching, I know what I'm doing right and wrong....and I do ask students mid-term for feedback.

It's with my colleagues that I feel the prejudice. I was passed over as chair of a committee I particularly related to even though I was the most senior member and one of the longest in the committee. The male chair chose a younger "buddy" as his successor. I am out-spoken and unafraid to voice my opinion. I think that is not perceived well with some male colleagues. When I do come up with a good idea, I often am ignored. The same idea brought up by a male colleague just a few minutes later is listened to with interest.

And it's not just me. Many of my female colleagues voice the same issues. So it's not just the students. And I wonder if my male colleagues unconsciously perpetuate the status quo. Do they recommend my classes? I wonder.

I am an old female with a degree in math and computer science. I wholeheartedly agree with your observation. Thankfully, I had many excellent math teachers, but I fear there are fewer today. How can we encourage more excellent math instructors, whatever the method, or gender of the instructor, to teach our students today. People who cannot teach mathematics should not be destroying our potential. When I graduated there were about 20 students in our group getting similar degrees -- none with honors cords. There were over 200 getting teaching degrees -- I think all had honors cords. It's no wonder our educational system isn't producing anyore.

Throughout my education, my math grades went up and down depending on the teacher. From junior High straight A's to the D with an awful misogynist geometry teacher that robbed me of the chance to take high school AP calculus, through the D's in college calculus lectures until I finally got a self-paced course with no lectures, in which I consistently earned A's. Then, D's in cookbook statistics classes taught by biologists followed by grad school statistics from a mathematician whose use of geometry allowed me to visualize analyses and resulted in me minoring in statistics for my PhD. Some of these swings had to do with the way the math was taught; in other cases there was clear misogyny. Ultimately, my statistics and math skills made me successful in my academic career of research and teaching science, but it would have been interesting to see what more I could have done had I consistently had good math teachers with good attitudes about female students.
